ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Error Analysis, Python Programming, Writing Lab Reports, and Experimental Design

Python was used throughout the course. I had no previous experience with it, so admittedly it was challenging at times, but most of the code was already provided and you could receive help at any time.
Knowledge of coding and data processing.

I regained my coding skills in python through continuous use of the programming language in class and in external assignments. I also developed a better understanding of error analysis (which, let us face it, is the bane of any young scientist). Finally, I strengthened my abilities at designing, conducting, managing, and finishing scientific projects.
I learned how to draft and execute an experimental setup as well as handle error analysis.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths

-great T.A : Joseph was incredibly helpful, both with academic and career questions and concerns 
- In my case, I learned a useful skill : python coding 
- The final project was open-ended, so it was nice to design something from start to finish 

Weaknesses 

It was online (nothing you can do about that)

The weaknesses of the course were due simply to the online format. These could not have been avoided. One thing that would have been nice is if there were more students in the class (there were three in my class including me), but I understand that is simply due to the number of enrollments.

Strengths: the course was well structured, and did its best to accommodate the students' needs. The course also worked remarkably smoothly considering that it was a lab class taught online. All materials for the course were provided via mail and the teachers set reasonable expectations given the limitations of what we had. 
On top of this, the class was itself very interesting, and I admit that I enjoyed messing about with the lab assignments.

I liked that they sent us iOLab devices so we could still perform labs, but sometimes the labs didnt feel very well structured and would have errors, leading to a very frustrating session where not much progress was made.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A lab class taught virtually in a pandemic is not going to be smooth. However, the professors knew this and therefore structured the lab in order to make is as manageable and flexible in the format as it could be. This made the class much easier and more enjoyable. I really appreciate the efforts that the professors and the TA's put in to making the experience as nice as possible.
I liked how they sent us to breakout rooms in small groups.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I do believe this is a requirement for physics majors, so I guess you have no choice. Having done it online, I can say it was a good experience and everything was laid out well. I cant speak for it good during offline/normal times ( though i only think it could improve, besides the walk up science hill)

I would recommend this course to another student, because it teaches the basics of the scientific method as well as the conceptual and creative skills a scientist needs in order to conduct their research projects. It is also fun to mess around with the lab materials.
Yes, if you plan on doing a physics major, but beware the workload is greater than 0.5 credits leads you to believe.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: No other modes (except independent meetings with the students outside of class to discuss class work).
We had live virtual lectures with breakout rooms.
